sentences.sentence: I share The Australian Financial Review's opinion that we have yet another election "without a credible agenda for critical issues" (The AFR View, May 2).It seems political agendas and choices here and, in truth, everywhere fall increasingly short of the scale of change required for capitalism to create productive, innovative, sustainable, inclusive and equitable societies.In the 19th century, ideas associated with conservatism, liberalism and socialism emerged as distinctive and overarching ideologies to provide a broadly based framework for the struggle over the future of capitalism.In this century, particularly in the electoral contests within the parliamentary democracies, the ambit of ideas and policies proposed and pursued has increasingly narrowed to become ineffectual.

It has become normalised for elections to be won on a policy agenda designed to fail.The influence and defence of the current variety of capitalism and its embedded sectoral interests has been sufficient to slow the changes needed to create either a better variety of capitalism or a transition to a fundamentally different economy and society.

A political treadmill has been created leaving conservatives, liberals and socialists all equally frustrated.More importantly, it leaves us with a variety of capitalism that threatens our existence and fails too many people too often.
We urgently need an expansion of the ideas and policies encompassed by the art of the politically possible.Stewart SweeneyAdelaide, SA

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
documents.inputText: I share The Australian Financial Review's opinion that we have yet another election "without a credible agenda for critical issues" (The AFR View, May 2).It seems political agendas and choices here and, in truth, everywhere fall increasingly short of the scale of change required for capitalism to create productive, innovative, sustainable, inclusive and equitable societies.In the 19th century, ideas associated with conservatism, liberalism and socialism emerged as distinctive and overarching ideologies to provide a broadly based framework for the struggle over the future of capitalism.In this century, particularly in the electoral contests within the parliamentary democracies, the ambit of ideas and policies proposed and pursued has increasingly narrowed to become ineffectual. It has become normalised for elections to be won on a policy agenda designed to fail.The influence and defence of the current variety of capitalism and its embedded sectoral interests has been sufficient to slow the changes needed to create either a better variety of capitalism or a transition to a fundamentally different economy and society. A political treadmill has been created leaving conservatives, liberals and socialists all equally frustrated.More importantly, it leaves us with a variety of capitalism that threatens our existence and fails too many people too often. We urgently need an expansion of the ideas and policies encompassed by the art of the politically possible.Stewart SweeneyAdelaide, SA
